Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2018 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Sophie T Spirkl is "Algorithms and structure for graphs with forbidden induced subgraphs". The host institution for the fellowship is Rutgers University and the sponsoring scientist is Jeff Kahn.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This goal of this project was to gain a better understanding of graphs with forbidden induced subgraphs: if a given local pattern never occurs in a larger object, does this imply the presence of global structure? Does it lead to more efficient algorithms? 


The Erdos-Hajnal conjecture is a long-standing fundamental conjecture about this local-global phenomenon in graphs with forbidden induced subgraphs, stating that such graphs have large cliques or stable sets (subsets of the vertex sets in which either all or no edges are present). During this project, the PI and her collaborators further developed the theory of "pure pairs", which are two subsets of the vertex set with all or no edges between them present. Many of these results have direct implications for the Erdos-Hajnal conjecture, and pure pairs themselves have emerged as a rich and interesting research area. Some of the new results pertain to ordered and bipartite graphs, which connects this to the study of 0/1-matrices with forbidden submatrices. 


Perhaps the most well-known class of graphs characterized by forbidden induced subgraphs is the class of perfect graphs, which famously can be described as graphs such that neither they nor their complements contain an odd hole. One of the results of this award is a new efficient algorithm for deciding if a graph contains an odd hole. This answers an open question, provides a new algorithm for testing if a graph is perfect, and improves our understanding of perfect graphs. 


Graph coloring is a global problem in graphs; it means partitioning the vertices of a graph into conflict-free sets. While there is generally no computationally efficient algorithm for this problem, in some cases the additional restriction of a forbidden induced subgraph makes the problem more tractable. This area of research is very active, with much of the efforts dedicated to resolving the complexity of 3-coloring graphs that do not contain an induced t-vertex path. The PI and her collaborators investigated and made progress on several variants of this problem; this includes an efficient algorithm for 3-coloring graphs with no induced t-vertex path and no induced 1-subdivision of a star. 


The results of this project have been disseminated as papers and through talks, including presentations for undergraduate students and women researchers. The PI has mentored several undergraduate students during this award, often as the student's first research experience.
